content: The Act may be cited as the "Department of Homeland Security Morale, Recognition, Learning and Engagement Act of 2017" or the "DHS MORALE Act". The Chief Human Capital Officer has specific responsibilities outlined in the Act. Section 704 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include leader development and employee engagement in policies, evaluate ongoing performance measures, and incorporate best practices from the Federal government and private sector. Amendments to Section 704 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 include incorporating leader development and employee engagement programs, evaluating performance measures, and implementing workforce planning initiatives based on employee feedback. Amendments to Section 704 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 include adding new paragraphs to maintain a catalogue of employee development opportunities, ensure compliance with employee discipline laws, and establish a Chief Learning and Engagement Officer position. The Chief Human Capital Officer may appoint a Chief Learning and Engagement Officer to support employee development opportunities and strategic workforce planning efforts within the Department. The Chief Human Capital Officer may appoint a Chief Learning and Engagement Officer to support strategic workforce planning efforts, including activities of the steering committee established under section 710(a). SEC. 3. EMPLOYEE ENGAGEMENT STEERING COMMITTEE AND ACTION PLAN. This section adds a new section to the Homeland Security Act of 2002 regarding employee engagement. The Secretary will establish an employee engagement steering committee within 120 days of the enactment of this section. The committee will include representatives from various departments and employee labor organizations to address factors impacting employee engagement and morale. The Secretary will establish an employee engagement steering committee to improve employee engagement, morale, and communications within the Department through initiatives, best practices, and monitoring efforts based on employee feedback. The committee will advise the Secretary on specific components and conduct regular meetings to report on Department-wide progress. The Secretary, through the Chief Human Capital Officer, will issue a Department-wide employee engagement action plan within 120 days of establishing a steering committee. The plan will aim to improve employee engagement, morale, and communications based on employee feedback from surveys and questionnaires. Each component head will be required to execute strategies outlined in the plan. The Department will require each component head to develop and implement a specific employee engagement plan, monitor progress, and provide quarterly reports to the Chief Human Capital Officer and steering committee. The steering committee receives quarterly reports on planned actions and progress made. This section will terminate five years after enactment. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents. Sec. 710 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 requires the Department of Homeland Security to submit an employee engagement action plan to Congress. Each component head must also submit specific plans to the Committee on Homeland Security. The Department of Homeland Security must submit component-specific employee engagement plans to Congress within 30 days of issuance, as required by section 710 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002. SEC. 4. ANNUAL EMPLOYEE AWARD PROGRAM. A new section is added to the Homeland Security Act of 2002 for an Annual Employee Award Program. The Secretary may establish an annual employee award program to recognize significant contributions by Department employees. This program includes categories of awards, nomination procedures, an internal review board, and recipient selection. The Secretary may establish an annual employee award program to recognize significant contributions by Department employees. The program includes categories of awards, nomination procedures, an internal review board, recipient selection, and publicizing the program within the Department. The internal review board consults with representatives from operational components, headquarters, and employee labor organizations. No additional funds are authorized for this program, and monetary bonuses are not required for award recipients. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 may be amended to include a new item related to employee awards. No additional funds are authorized for this program, and monetary bonuses are not required for award recipients. SEC. 711 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 establishes an annual employee award program without additional funds or mandatory monetary bonuses for recipients. The Comptroller General of the United States will investigate the equitable and consistent application of discipline and adverse actions in the Department of Homeland Security for misconduct by employees. The Comptroller General of the United States will consult with the employee engagement steering committee to review findings and recommendations of an investigation into employee misconduct in the Department of Homeland Security. The Under Secretary for Management will implement a plan to address any identified deficiencies in consultation with the committee. The committee will review the plan to inform their activities and action plans authorized under section 710. SEC. 5. PROHIBITION ON NEW FUNDING. No additional funds authorized for Act requirements. Funds to be used from existing authorizations.
